multimedia.caption: Gjelina’s Roasted Yams
multimedia.credit: Grant Cornett for The New York Times. Food stylist: Maggie Ruggiero. Prop stylist: Rebecca Bartoshesky.

multimedia.caption: Gjelina’s Roasted Yams
multimedia.credit: Grant Cornett for The New York Times. Food stylist: Maggie Ruggiero. Prop stylist: Rebecca Bartoshesky.

docs.lead_paragraph: These roasted yams are adapted from a recipe that Travis Lett, the chef and an owner of Gjelina in Venice, Calif., published in a 2015 cookbook devoted to the restaurant’s food. They are a marvelous accompaniment to a roast chicken, but they are maybe even better as a platter to accompany a salad of hearty greens, cheese and nuts. What makes them memorable is a technique Lett calls for during the cooking: tossing the tubers in honey before roasting them, which intensifies their caramelizing. The crisp, near-burned sweetness works beautifully against the heat of the pepper and the acidic creaminess of the yogurt you dab onto the dish at the end. It is a simple dish, but it results in fantastic eating.

headline.main: The Best Cuisine on Antarctic Ice

docs.abstract: The continuous and monotonous state of sensory deprivation caused by months of isolation means life in the Antarctic winter quickly becomes black and white in every sense -- except taste.

headline.main: Bengali Cuisine in the Suburbs of Mumbai

docs.abstract: Luckily homesick Bengalis in Mumbai -- and for food-curious visitors -- the quickly expanding chain Hangla's (Bengali for "glutton") is making Kolkata-style street food increasingly available, especially across the city's northern suburbs.
docs.lead_paragraph: It's no secret that Mumbai, with its economic might and reputation as "the city of dreams," attracts migrants and transplants from all over India. Among this crowd, there's a sizable contingent of Bengalis, homesick for the kabobs and biryanis of Calcutta. Luckily for them -- and for food-curious visitors -- the quickly expanding chain Hangla's (Bengali for "glutton") is making Calcutta-style street food increasingly available, particularly across the city's northern suburbs.
docs.snippet: Luckily homesick Bengalis in Mumbai -- and for food-curious visitors -- the quickly expanding chain Hangla's (Bengali for "glutton") is making Kolkata-style street food increasingly available, especially across the city's northern suburbs....

headline.main: Street Cuisine Finally Gets Its Due

docs.lead_paragraph: THEY have fans, but they're not stars. Customers rave about their food, but they're rarely, if ever, reviewed. Their specialties are discussed by connoisseurs throughout the city, but they labor in obscurity. But now the sidewalk food vendors of New York City are being recognized. In October, the Street Vendor Project, part of the Urban Justice Center, an advocacy group, will announce the Vendy Awards, presented to the best food vendors in the city.
docs.snippet: The Street Vendor Project will announce the Vendy Awards presented to the best street food vendors in the city....

headline.main: Michelin's Briton Keeps France's Cuisine Haute

docs.abstract: Profile and interview with Derek Brown, Englishman who is first non-Frenchman to head Michelin guides to hotels and restaurants in Michelen publications' 103-year history; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: DEREK BROWN strides into the room, all brisk self-assurance, firm handshake, impeccable tailoring, dossier-laden assistant four paces behind. A prosperous banker, perhaps, or a clever chap in the City. But this is not London, and while Mr. Brown is unmistakably Anglo-Saxon, as they say here, he is neither banker nor broker. He runs the quintessential French business: publishing the world's most prominent assessment of the best in restaurants and hotels, the Michelin Guides. He is the first non-Frenchman to head Michelin publications in their 103-year history.

headline.main: Vietnamese Cuisine That Plays Long Shots

docs.abstract: William Grimes reviews TanDa, Vietnamese restaurant on Park Avenue South; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: VIETNAMESE may or may not have a word for chutzpah, but TanDa has plenty of it, regardless. Not too many people would look at an old Off-Track Betting parlor on a murky, nearly deserted stretch of Park Avenue South and see the romantic outlines of a swanky Asian bistro and lounge. It takes nerve to unleash a chef like Stanley Wong, whose idiosyncratic interpretation of Southeast Asian cuisine walks a fine line between provocation and insolence. Finally, as a purely commercial venture, TanDa represents a bold gamble for its owners, who landed a coup with the painfully fashionable Moomba but have decided, this time around, to make an impression with serious, adventurous food. TanDa, named after a 20th-century Vietnamese poet, does make an impression. New York has seen its share of Asian fusion cooking, but Mr. Wong, who has an unusual résumé, strikes out for new territory, foraging far and wide for ingredients and employing them in unusual ways. Prickly ash berry jus, to cite one example, stumped me momentarily. It appears with a sizable New York strip steak with a peppery crust, and therein lies the solution to this minor mystery. Prickly ash is the tree better known for its dried fruit, Sichuan pepper, and Mr. Wong's scorching steak surprise turns out to be a scorching Asian steak au poivre.
